Graphical abstract A novel biosynthesized nanocatalyst, iron oxide-loaded manganese dioxide nanocomposites (Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs), was fabricated with the aid of a Perilla frutescens leaf extract. The MnO2 is composed of numerous nanoflakes radiating from the center, which results to a flowerlike structure. A change in the flowerlike morphology of MnO2 in Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs was observed due to the distribution of Fe3O4 nanoparticles on the surface of MnO2. To check the catalytic performance of the synthesized NCs, they were utilized as a catalyst for the decolorization of rhodamine B (RhB), reduction of 4-nitroaniline (4-NA), and sp3 C–H functionalization of 2-methylpyridines to isatins for the synthesis of azaarene-substituted 3-hydroxy-2-oxindole derivatives. The Fe3O4-loaded MnO2 exhibited enhanced catalytic ability over MnO2. Moreover, the nanocomposites could be recovered by a magnetic separation technique and reused for five consecutive reactions without significant loss of catalytic ability. Keywords Nanocomposites Perilla frutescens Rhodamine B 4-Nitroaniline Azaarenes 1 Introduction Manganese dioxide, a transition metal oxide, has attracted considerable attention for its chemical and physical characteristics as well as its versatile applications in catalysis [1,2], wastewater treatment [3], batteries [4], and supercapacitors [5]. This material has been used as a heterogeneous catalyst in numerous industrial applications, such as the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide [6], selective oxidation of ethylbenzene [7], 2-propanol [8,9], carbon monoxide [10], and ethanol [11], ozone decomposition [12], photocatalytic oxidation of organic pollutants [13], hydrogenation of carbon monoxide [14], and nitric oxide reduction [15–17]. On the other hand, MnO2 alone as a catalyst is often disadvantageous for industrial applications because powder catalysts can be lost easily during a reaction and cannot be separated well. Moreover, an efficient protocol for catalyst recovery is crucial for the applied field. Therefore, to enhance its capabilities and prevent its loss during recycling, magnetic separation technology with unique magnetic properties and variable surface properties has been applied [18]. Fe3O4 nanoparticles distributed on the surface of MnO2 provide a very facile protocol for the removal and recycling of magnetic nanocomposites (NCs) using an external magnetic field. Moreover, the bifunctional NCs can be recovered easily and their durability can be increased for the sustainable development of other catalysts [19,20]. The aim of this study was to biosynthesize nanoparticles using a plant extract, which is a facile, green, low-cost, and environmentally friendly approach. Here, Perilla frutescens L. (Lamiaceae) was used to synthesize Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs, MnO2, and Fe3O4. P. frutescens is a perennial plant cultivated in East Asia, and both the leaves and seeds are used as ingredients in Korean cuisine. This plant is commonly known for its antioxidant [21] and antiallergic [22] properties. Phytochemical studies revealed the presence of a variety of flavonoids and polyphenols such as gallic acid, apigenin, luteolin, rosmarinic acid, anthocyanins, tormentic acid, oleanolic acid, and ursolic acid [23–25]. To check the catalytic performance of the synthesized nanocomposites, the decolorization of an organic dye, rhodamine B (RhB), and the reduction of 4-nitroaniline (4-NA) were carried out. Although the nitroaromatics are industrially useful compounds [26,27], they have been reported to be environmentally hazardous [28,29]. Moreover, further reaction for the construction of azaarene-substituted 3-hydroxy-2-oxindole derivatives was attempted via sp3 C–H functionalization of 2-methylpyridines to isatins. Substituted 3-hydroxy-2-oxindoles are an important class of naturally occurring molecules used largely in pharmaceutical materials [30–32]. These compounds have a variety of potent biological and pharmaceutical activities, such as anti-HIV, antioxidant, anticancer, and neuroprotective properties [33–35]. Moreover, the C3-substituted oxindoles show more biological activity [36]. Their wide range of biological activity has stimulated interest in the development of facile and efficient syntheses of 3-substituted 3-hydroxy-2-oxindoles, which involves C–C bond formation via sp3 C–H bond activation of 2-methylpyridines. Therefore, the development of a novel and facile synthetic protocol for the synthesis of these derivatives bearing the biologically active azaarene-substituted 3-hydroxy-2-oxindoles has become an ongoing challenge. Many nanomaterials have been reported as catalysts to degrade harmful organic dyes or reduce nitroaromatic compounds. On the other hand, in comparison with the several reported nanoparticle catalysts [37–42], the synthesized Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs exhibited the best catalytic performance for the decolorization of RhB dye and the reduction of 4-NA. Although there are few reports of the sp3 C–H functionalization of 2-methylpyridines to isatins for synthesizing azaarene-substituted 3-hydroxy-2-oxindoles [43], there is a need for convenient, safer, and cost-effective protocols involving easily available and environmentally friendly recyclable and reusable catalysts. This paper reports an easy and green approach to the preparation of Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs, MnO2, and Fe3O4 using P. frutescens leaf extract. The biosynthesized NCs were used as recyclable and reusable catalysts for the decolorization of RhB, reduction of 4-NA, and sp3 C–H functionalization of 2-methylpyridines to isatins for the synthesis of azaarene-substituted 3-hydroxy-2-oxindole derivatives, without any significant loss of catalytic activity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods Potassium permanganate (KMnO4, ⩾99%), iron (III) chloride (FeCl3, 97%), iron (II) sulfate heptahydrate (FeSO4·7H2O, ⩾99%), rhodamine B (RhB, ⩾95%), 4-nitroaniline (4-NA, ⩾99%), sodium borohydride (NaBH4, ⩾99%), isatin, 5-methylisatin, 5-chloroisatin, 5-nitroisatin, 2,3-lutidine, 2,6-lutidine, and 2-picoline were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. All chemicals were used as received. The air dried leaves of P. frutescens was obtained from a local market in Yeongchon, South Korea. The P. frutescens leaf extract was prepared using a previous method with slight modifications [44]. A 15g sample of the powdered leaves was prewetted with an NH4OH solution and 100mL of deionized Milli-Q water was added. The resulting mixture was then boiled for 10min and filtered. 2.2 Synthesis of MnO2 A 10mL volume of the P. frutescens leaf extract solution was added to 100mL of 0.1M KMnO4 aqueous solution. The mixture solution was refluxed for 12h. After 12h, a brown precipitate was formed, indicating the formation of MnO2. Here, the MnO4 − was reduced to MnO2 by polyols present in the plant extract. The precipitate was isolated by centrifugation (10,000rpm, 4°C, and 15min), washed with water, and dried in a vacuum oven for 3h. 2.3 Synthesis of Fe3O4 A 10mL volume of the P. frutescens leaf extract solution was added to 100mL of an aqueous solution of FeCl3 and FeSO4 (2:1) solution. The mixture was then refluxed for 2h. The black precipitate formed was isolated by centrifugation (10,000rpm, 4°C, and 15min), washed with water, and dried in a vacuum oven for 3h. 2.4 Synthesis of Fe3O4–MnO2 nanocomposites using plant extract A 100mg sample of synthesized MnO2 was dispersed in 50mL water by ultrasonication for 30min. Subsequently, 100mL of an aqueous solution of FeCl3 and FeSO4 (2:1) was added to the dispersed solution. A 10mL sample of the P. frutescens leaf extract solution was added and refluxed for 2h. The black precipitate formed was isolated by centrifugation (10,000rpm, 4°C, and 15min), washed with water, and dried in a vacuum oven for 3h. 2.5 Synthesis of Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs using gallic acid A 10mL volume of the 1mmol solution of gallic acid was added to 100mL of 0.1M KMnO4 aqueous solution. The mixture was refluxed for 12h. After 12h, a brown precipitate was formed, indicating the formation of MnO2. Subsequently, 100mL of an aqueous solution of FeCl3 and FeSO4 (2:1) was added to the MnO2 solution. Further, 10mL of the 1mmol aqueous solution of gallic acid was added and refluxed for 2h. The black precipitate formed was isolated by centrifugation (10,000rpm, 4°C, and 15min), washed with water, and dried in a vacuum oven for 3h. 2.6 UV–visible analysis of total flavonoids and phenolic acid present in P. frutescens The total flavonoids available in P. frutescens leaf extract were determined using an aluminum chloride colorimetric method with minor changes [45]. A 2.0mL aliquot of the leaf extract was added to 0.50mL of a 10% aluminum chloride solution (w/v) along with 0.10mL of 1M potassium acetate and 3mL of distilled water. The mixture was left to stand at room temperature for 30min. The absorbance of the resulting solution at 415nm was observed against a reagent blank using an UV–visible spectrophotometer. The analysis was performed three times for consistent results. The result is reported as grams of quercetin equivalent (QE) per 100g dried weight of leaves. The total phenolic acid present in the P. frutescens leaf extract was determined using the Folin-Ciocalteu calorimetric method [46]. A 1.5mL sample of diluted Folin–Ciocalteu reagent (2/20) was added to 1.0mL of leaf extract and left to stand for 5min at room temperature. Subsequently, 1.5mL of 7% sodium carbonate (w/v) was added to the mixture to neutralize it and kept in the dark at room temperature for 90min. The absorbance was taken at 765nm against a reagent blank using an UV–visible spectrophotometer. The analysis was performed three times for consistent results. The result is reported as grams of gallic acid equivalent (GAE) per 100g dried weight of leaves. 2.7 Characterization of nanocomposites Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed to determine the crystalline nature of the nanoparticles using a PANalytical X’PertPRO MPD (operating at 40kV and 30mA with Cu Kα as the X-ray source (λ =1.5406Å) over the range 10–80° 2θ, at a scanning rate of 1.2°/min). The surface chemistry of the nanoparticles and the chemical state of each element were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha system) using an Al Kα X-ray light source. The ion source energy was 100V to 3keV for the survey. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Perkin–Elmer FTIR spectrometer in transmittance mode over the range 400–4000cm−1. The Raman spectra were observed using XploRA Plus, HORIBA Scientific, with a TE air-cooled CCD detector. The samples were excited at 532nm with a YAG (Nd) laser; the spectral resolution was approximately 3cm−1, and the spectrum acquisition time was 100s. The morphology of the nanoparticles was observed by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, S4200, Hitachi, Ltd.,) with a resolution of 1.5nm. The shape and size of the nanoparticles were analyzed by field emission transmission electron microscopy (FE-TEM, FEI Tecnai F20). The samples were prepared on carbon-coated copper grids by placing a drop of the nanoparticle solutions on the grids and allowing the solvent to evaporate in air at ambient temperature. The elemental makeup of the bimetallic nanoparticles was analyzed by high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (HAADF-STEM-EDS) at 200kV with a point resolution of 0.24nm, a Cs and Cc of 1.2mm each, and a focal length of 1.7mm, using a Genesis liquid-nitrogen-cooled EDS detector with an ultrathin window. The concentration of Fe and Mn species in solution was determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES), Perkin–Elmer Optima 8300. The thermal properties of the nanoparticles were analyzed by thermogravimetric analysis coupled with differential scanning calorimetry (DSC-TGA, SDT-Q600 V20.5 Build 15) and heated under N2 to 700°C at 10°Cmin−1. The formation of nanoparticles was monitored using an Optizen 3220 (Double beam) UV–vis spectrophotometer with a quartz cuvette and distilled water as the reference. The magnetic susceptibility and magnetization were investigated by quantum design vibrating sample magnetometry (VSM Lake Shore Cryotronics, Inc., Idea-VSM, Model 662 with 735 VSM controller) at room temperature in an applied magnetic field sweeping from −5 to 5kOe. The zeta-potential measurements were performed by dynamic light scattering (DLS, Malvern Zetasizer, UK). The sample was equilibrated for 2min at 25°C and the analysis was repeated three times for consistent results. Atomic force microscopy (AFM, Nanoscope IIIa, Digital Instruments, Inc., USA) was operated in tapping mode using standard silicon nitride tips. 2.8 Catalytic activity The synthesized Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs, MnO2, and Fe3O4 were employed as catalysts to examine their versatility and catalytic efficiency. 2.8.1 Decolorization of RhB (R1) RhB was chosen to check the ability of the dye decolorization activity of the nanocomposites to overcome its low degradability via previously reported photochemical approaches [47,48]. A 2.0mL aqueous solution of RhB (0.025mM) and 0.4mL of 0.2M NaBH4 was taken and a 100μL aqueous solution of well dispersed Fe3O4-MnO2 NCs (0.2mg, 2mg/mL) was added. The UV–vis spectra against time were recorded at room temperature (25±1°C). After the complete decolorization of RhB, the catalyst was recovered by an external magnet, washed with dichloromethane, and dried at 80°C. The recovered catalyst was then reused in the subsequent reactions under identical conditions. 2.8.2 Reduction of 4-NA (R2) The reduction of 4-NA was performed to evaluate the catalytic performance of the synthesized Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs and MnO2. A 2.0mL sample of an aqueous solution of 4-NA (0.025mM) and 0.4mL of 0.2M NaBH4 was taken and a 100μL aqueous solution of well-dispersed Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs (0.2mg, 2mg/mL) was added. The UV–vis spectra against time were recorded ​at room temperature (25±1°C). After the complete reduction of 4-NA, the catalyst was recovered by an external magnet, washed with dichloromethane, and dried at 80°C. The recovered catalyst was then reused in the subsequent reactions under identical conditions. 2.8.3 sp3 C–H functionalization of 2-methylpyridines to isatins (R3) To a solution of isatins (1.0mmol) and methylpyridine (2.5mmol) in water (10mL), was added Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs (6.37mg, 2mol.%) or MnO2 (1.75mg, 2mol.%) at room temperature. The reaction mixture was then heated under reflux for 1h. After the reaction was complete, the catalyst was recovered using an external magnet, washed with dichloromethane, and dried at 80°C. The recovered catalyst was then reused in the subsequent reactions under identical conditions. After the catalyst was recovered, the solvent was removed using a reduced pressure evaporator. The residue was purified by column chromatography on a silica gel to give the product. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Role of plant extract in the formation of MnO2 and Fe3O4–MnO2 nanocomposites The MnO2 and Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs were synthesized by a green protocol using P. frutescens leaf extract. The phytochemical ingredients (in terms of concentration/amount) of the leaf extract included gallic acid (1.39g of GAE/100g), apigenin (0.119g/100g), luteolin (0.157g/100g), rosmarinic acid (1.14g/100g), anthocyanins (2.9μmol/100mL of cyanidin equivalent), tormentic acid (0.02mg/100g), oleanolic acid (0.1mg/100g), and ursolic acid (0.4mg/100g) (Fig. S1, ESI). Aside from the gallic acid content, all other acid content was taken from the reported literature [23–25]. These phytoconstituents may be responsible for the selective formation of the MnO2. The phenolic hydroxyl groups of gallic acid can reduce the MnO4 − to MnO2 by electron transfer. In addition, the plant extracts act as capping agents, stabilize the MnO2, and restrict the formation of other manganese oxides (Mn2O3, Mn3O4, MnO), as confirmed by XRD [49,50]. Furthermore, the gallic acid can serve as a reductant in solution due to its hydroxyl groups and reduce the free iron ions in aqueous solution to Fe3O4 nanoparticles [51]. The spherical Fe3O4 nanoparticles thus formed are distributed on the surface of the MnO2, as depicted by SEM and TEM analysis. NH4OH has been used to extract the flavonoid and polyphenolic compounds [52,53]. In addition, NH4OH may contribute to the precipitation of the salt used for the synthesis of the catalysts, but the plant extract solution was boiled for 10min, eliminating the NH3. 3.2 Characterization of MnO2 and Fe3O4–MnO2 nanocomposites X-ray diffraction was performed to determine the crystallinity and composition of the NCs (Fig. 1 a). The XRD peaks for the Fe3O4–MnO2 at 30.24°, 35.61°, 43.06°, 56.95°, and 62.68° 2θ were assigned to the respective reflection planes (220), (311), (400), (511), and (440), which could be assigned to magnetite (JCPDS: 19-0629). The XRD peaks at 12.31°, 36.88°, and 65.61° 2θ were attributed to the reflection planes (001), (−111), and (020) of MnO2 (JCPDS card no. 80-1098) [54–56]. Peak broadening and peak height lowering of MnO2 were observed due to the loss of crystallinity of MnO2 when Fe3O4 was added. Moreover, the XRD pattern of Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs synthesized using gallic acid did not show clear peaks. Interestingly, the Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs synthesized using P. frutescens leaf extract showed distinct peaks, which confirmed that the polyphenols, flavonoids, and other bioactive molecules present in the plant extract act collectively as reducing and capping agents. Furthermore, XPS was used to examine the surface chemistry, i.e., elemental composition and oxidation states of the Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs. Fig. 1b shows two peaks with binding energies of 710.47 and 723.87eV, which were assigned to Fe2p 3/2 and Fe2p 1/2, respectively. These peaks consist of Fe3+ (Fe2O3) and Fe2+ (FeO), which are characteristic of the Fe3O4 structure [57]. Apart from the characteristic peaks of the Fe3O4 nanostructure, the air-oxidized surface of Fe3O4 comprised a satellite peak at around 718eV, which was due to γ-Fe2O3 [58,59]. The binding energies of Mn2p 3/2 and Mn2p 1/2 were 642.38 and 654.18eV (Fig. 1c), respectively, which reveals the presence of Mn4+ ions in the oxide and is in good agreement with the reported MnO2 [60,61]. The slight shift in the binding energies of MnO2 at 642.04 (Mn2p 3/2) and 653.84 (Mn2p 1/2) was attributed to the strong interaction between Mn4+ and Fe3+/Fe2+ through the oxygen atom [62]. Due to the strong interaction between Mn4+ and Fe3+/Fe2+ through the oxygen atom, the shoulder peak of Mn2p 3/2 in between 642.5 and 645eV disappears when Fe3O4 is added to MnO2. The spin–energy splitting of 2p 3/2 and 2p 1/2 was 11.8eV, which was attributed to the coupling of angular momentum related to the partially filled core and valence shells with the unpaired electrons of Mn4+ [63–65]. As the valence of Mn is flexible, the average oxidation state of Mn in manganese oxides can be determined by the spin–energy separation (4.8eV) of the Mn 3s doublet peaks (Fig. S2, ESI) [66,67]. This spin splitting indicates that the Mn in the nanocomposites has an oxidation state of 4. The unsymmetrical O1s peak could be deconvoluted into two parts (Fig. 1d). The one at 529.7eV was assigned to the surface lattice oxygen species and the one at 531.5eV was assigned to the surface adsorbed oxygen species [68–70]. In addition, the surface nature of Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs was confirmed by FTIR spectroscopy (Fig. 2 a). The absorption peak at 566cm−1 was assigned to the Fe–O stretching vibrations, which became sharp and broad due to the increased Mn–O peak strength [71]. The peaks at 1426 and 1637cm−1 correspond to the symmetric C–O stretching and the asymmetric stretching of COO− of the bioactive molecules present in the plant extract. The sharp peaks at 421 and 498cm−1 can be attributed to the Mn–O stretching vibrations in MnO2 [72]. On the other hand, Raman spectroscopy can analyze the spectra of interfaces between two components [73]. Therefore, Raman spectroscopy was performed to confirm the presence of Fe3O4 nanoparticles distributed on the surface of MnO2. The pure MnO2 phase shows a sharp Raman band at 643cm−1 (Fig. 2b). In Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs, the MnO2 phase possesses a broad band at 631cm−1, which accounts for the Fe–Mn bonds due to the distribution of Fe3O4 nanoparticles over the surface of the MnO2 [74–76] (Fig. 2b). Two prominent bands at a lower Raman shift, 221 and 279cm−1, may be due to the vibration modes of Fe–O bonds of Fe3O4 nanoparticles [77,78]. The morphology, size distribution, and orientation of the nanocomposites were analyzed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). SEM revealed the nanoflower morphology of MnO2 (Fig. 3 a) [79]. The as-synthesized MnO2 nanoparticles had a flowerlike structure linked with one another in the chain (Fig. 3b). The flowerlike MnO2 were composed of numerous nanoflakes radiating from the center (Fig. 3c). The HRTEM image reveals continuous and prominent lattice fringes in a single nanoflake, depicting the crystalline nature of the nanoflakes. As shown in Fig. 3d, the lattice fringes of the MnO2 nanoflake were found to be 0.67, which is in good agreement with the results reported for MnO2 [80–83]. These MnO2 nanoflakes were found to be less than 5nm in thickness. Fig. 3f revealed multiple diffraction rings, indicating the crystallinity of MnO2 nanoflakes. MnO2 contains Mn and O elements without impurities, which were assigned by STEM-EDS elemental mapping (Fig. 4 a–d), and was further confirmed by EDS (Fig. S3a, ESI). Fig. 5 a shows a change in the morphology of MnO2 in Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs as depicted by SEM images and Raman spectra. The change in the flowerlike morphology of MnO2 in Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs was observed due to the loading of Fe3O4 nanoparticles on the MnO2 surface (Fig. 5b–e). The HRTEM image of the nanoflake with a lattice fringe of 0.67nm is due to the interplanar spacing of the (001) plane of MnO2 (Fig. 5d) [80–83]. Furthermore, the d-spacing observed was 0.26nm, which correlates with the crystal face of the (311) planes of Fe3O4 (Fig. 5c and d) [18]. The mean size of Fe3O4 particles was around 5nm (Fig. 5c), which is consistent with the result obtained from the XRD using the Scherrer formula (∼6nm). The selected area diffraction (SAED) pattern confirms the crystalline nature of Fe3O4–MnO2, with multiple diffraction rings from the inside to the outside (Fig. 5f). In addition, high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM), along with EDS elemental mapping, confirmed the presence of Fe, Mn, and O elements (Fig. 6 a–d), showing that the iron oxides are distributed on the surface of the MnO2. The elemental composition was assigned using EDS coupled with TEM, which showed that the characteristic peaks for Mn, Fe, and O (Fig. S3b, ESI), along with those for Cu and C, arise from the carbon coated copper grid. The overlapping signals of the Fe and Mn nanocomposites at ∼6.5keV were probably due to the close energy levels [84–86]. The EDS analysis revealed that Fe was 6.47wt.% of Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs, which was further confirmed by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) with an Fe loading of 6.98wt.%. The thermal stability of MnO2 and Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs were analyzed by DSC-TGA (Fig. 7 ). TGA revealed the weight loss percentage during heating to 700°C at 10°Cmin−1 under N2. As the temperature reached 700°C, the total weight loss for MnO2 and Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs was 24.59% and 18.50%, respectively. In MnO2, a rapid weight loss in the TGA curve was observed, showing sharp endothermic peaks at 44.07, 210.36, and 499.59°C. The mass loss (4.19%) between 400 and 600°C may be due to the surface oxygen loss in the MnO2 lattice [83,87,88], which correlates well with the sharp peak observed in the DSC curve. Similarly, for Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs, the initial weight loss (6.87%) below 100°C can be attributed to the evaporation of volatile matter and adsorbed moisture retained in the nanoparticles. This feature is reflected further by the endothermic DSC peak at approximately 40°C. The abrupt weight loss (7.31%) after 200°C, which corresponds with the endothermic peak on the DSC curve at around 273.61°C, may be due to the removal of capping agents present in the P. frutescens leaf extract. The sharp weight loss after 400°C was not observed in the case of Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs. This was attributed to the strong interaction between Fe3+/Fe2+ and Mn4+ through the oxygen atom, which was distributed on the surface of MnO2, as confirmed by XPS. The residual mass for MnO2 and Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs was found to be 75.41% and 81.50%, respectively (Figs. S4 and S5, ESI), which further confirmed the capping of the nanoparticles by the plant extract, leaving the Fe3O4 and MnO2 residues behind. The total flavonoids and phenolic acid content in the P. frutescens leaf extract were found to be 1.88±0.28g of QE per 100g dried weight of leaves and 1.39±0.13g of GAE per100g dried weight of leaves, respectively. The optical properties of the nanocomposites were analyzed using a facile preliminary approach by UV–visible spectroscopy. The appearance of a broad band at approximately 370nm, with the disappearance of KMnO4 peaks, indicated the formation of MnO2 [89]. The continuous absorption, along with the small peak at approximately 350nm, confirmed the formation of Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs (Fig. S6a, ESI). The peak in between 250 and 300nm confirmed the presence of polyols present in the P. frutescens leaf extract (Fig. S6b, ESI). The hysteresis loops of Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs depicted by VSM analysis at 300K (Fig. 8 a) showed that the nanocomposites are ferromagnetic in nature with a saturation magnetization (Ms) of 16.2emu/g, so it is easier to recover from the reaction mixture using an external magnetic field. The Ms value of Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs is lower than that of Fe3O4, which may be due to the presence of paramagnetic MnO2 (Fig. 8b) [90]. The coercivity (Hc) and remanent magnetization (Mr) vary in both the Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs and Fe3O4. The lower coercivity (19.5Oe) of Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs represents a soft magnet [91]. The surface charge and stability of the MnO2 and Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs were assigned using a zeta potentiometer. A single zeta potential distribution peak was observed (Figs. S7 and S8, ESI). For MnO2, the average zeta potential (−25.4±1.47mV) and zeta deviation (5.07±0.40mV) were observed (Table S1, ESI). Similarly, the average zeta potential and zeta deviation of Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs were −1.09±0.18 and 3.90±0.53mV, respectively (Table S2, ESI), which indicates the stability of the biosynthesized nanocomposites in a colloidal solution [92]. These negative values confirmed the capping of Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs and MnO2 with negatively charged biomolecules present in the P. frutescens leaf extract [93]. The surface roughness of the nanocomposites was characterized by AFM. The nanocomposites were dispersed in water by sonication for 10min. A drop of this colloidal solution was added to the silica vapor glass plate and dried at room temperature. The AFM data was processed to 2D and 3D color map images (Fig. 9 ). The quality of the AFM image was determined by the nature and position of the tip and other parameters such as the applied force, oscillation amplitude, and scanning rate [94]. The mean roughness of MnO2 and Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs was 0.608 and 0.715nm, respectively (Fig. S9, ESI). Moreover, the surface roughness of the nanocomposites was determined further by the section analysis of the AFM image. The maximum height observed from the section profile analysis of the respective MnO2 and Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs was 0.611 and 1.097nm at two different lines (Fig. S10, ESI). 3.3 Catalytic activity of Fe3O4, MnO2 and Fe3O4–MnO2 nanocomposites 3.3.1 Catalytic decolorization of RhB (R1) To explore the catalytic performance of Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs, MnO2, and Fe3O4, the catalytic decolorization of RhB by NaBH4 was measured using a slight modification of the method reported [95]. The decolorization of RhB was monitored by UV–vis spectroscopy. The plausible catalytic mechanism for the decolorization of RhB is depicted in Scheme 1 . As the RhB is electrophilic and BH4 − is nucleophilic in nature, the metallic nanoparticles act as electron relays in redox reactions. Here, the nucleophile NaBH4 donates electrons to the Fe nanoparticles, and the electrophile RhB (1) captures the electrons from the Fe nanoparticles to give intermediate 3 [96,97]. The decolorization process led to the saturation of the central carbon atom by the substitution of a hydrogen atom at this position in the intermediate 3 (Leuco RhB), which is cyclized to give the colorless product 4 [98]. The characteristic absorption peak of RhB at 554nm disappeared in 90s in the presence of NaBH4 and Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs (Fig. 10 a). The decolorization of RhB followed the first-order kinetics and the apparent rate constant calculated for the Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs, MnO2, and Fe3O4 were 8.2×10−2, 7.6×10−2, and 2.5×10−2 s−1, respectively (Fig. 10b). These results show enhanced catalytic activity of Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs over MnO2 and Fe3O4. 3.3.2 Catalytic reduction of 4-NA (R2) The reduction reaction of 4-NA was performed to explore the catalytic ability of Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs, MnO2, and Fe3O4. Fig. 11 a shows the UV–vis spectra for the catalytic reduction of 4-NA by NaBH4 in the presence of Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs. The typical absorption peak of 4-NA at 380nm disappeared in 50s in the presence of NaBH4 and Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs. In the meantime, two peaks at 240 and 300nm were observed, which were attributed to the formation of p-phenylenediamine [95]. The reduction of 4-NA followed the first-order kinetics, and the apparent rate constant calculated for the Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs, MnO2, and Fe3O4 was 13.8×10−2 s−1, 5.7×10−2 s−1, and 5.3×10−2 s−1, respectively (Fig. 11b). The observed highest reaction rate and activity parameter of Fe3O4-MnO2 NCs for both the decolorization of RhB (Table 1 ) and the reduction of 4-NA (Table 2 ) demonstrate the enhanced catalytic activity of Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs over MnO2 and Fe3O4, showing a strong synergistic effect of Fe3O4 loaded onto MnO2. Similarly, the observed reaction rate of Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs GA for both the decolorization of RhB (8.0×10−2 s−1) and the reduction of 4-NA (10.1×10−2 s−1) further confirms that the catalytic activity of Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs synthesized from the plant extract is better than that of the Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs using gallic acid and other reported nanocatalysts [41,97,99]. 3.3.3 sp3 C–H functionalization of 2-methylpyridines to isatins (R3) To further broaden the catalytic efficiency of the Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs, MnO2, and Fe3O4, a reaction of isatin (1a), and 2,3-lutidine (2a) was refluxed in water (10mL) in the presence of 2mol.% of the Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs (6.37mg), MnO2 (1.75mg), or Fe3O4 (4.63mg), as shown in Scheme 2 . The expected product 3a was obtained in high yield (91%). The product 3a was determined by an analysis of its spectral data and compared with the reported data [43]. To synthesize a variety of azaarene-substituted 3-hydroxy-2-oxindole derivatives, the reactions of substituted isatins bearing either electron-donating or electron-withdrawing groups and 2,3-lutidine (2a), 2,6-lutidine (2b), or 2-picoline (2c) gave the desired products 3b–3e in 80–90% yield. Moreover, the reaction using its monometallic nanoparticles, such as MnO2 or Fe3O4 NPs, afforded the desired product 3a in 61 and 53% yield, respectively, but no product was formed with the P. frutescens extract only. These results showed that the biosynthesized Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs exhibit enhanced catalytic ability with respect to the product yield compared with its monometallic counterparts (Table 3 ), due to the strong synergistic effect of Fe3O4 loaded on MnO2. In addition, the yield of the product 3a obtained using Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs PE (91%) was observed to be higher than that of the Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs GA (87%). Scheme 3 presents a plausible reaction mechanism for the formation of 3a. The 2,3-lutidine (2a) in the presence of nanocomposites gives the N-pyridinium cation 4. The C–H bond cleavage of 4 generates the enamine intermediate 5, which then undergoes nucleophilic addition to isatin (1a) to give product 3a. 3.4 Recyclability and reusability of the Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs The recycling experiment was undertaken to check the stability and catalytic activity of the biosynthesized Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs. The catalyst was recovered from the reaction mixture by an external magnet due to the ferromagnetic nature of the nanocomposites. After separation, the catalyst was washed with dichloromethane and dried in a vacuum oven for 3h. The magnetically recovered nanocatalyst was then reused five times for consecutive reactions under identical conditions. Significantly, there was no loss of catalytic activity in any of the three reactions (R1, R2, & R3), as shown in Fig. 12 . The XPS spectra of the Fe and Mn species taken after the fifth cycle confirm the retention of the catalytic activity of the Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs (Fig. 13 ). Moreover, the oxidation states of Fe3O4 did not change except for the appearance of the satellite peak, which was formed due to the air-exposed oxidized surface of Fe3O4 (Fig. 13a). The leaching of Fe and Mn species in the R3 solution was analyzed by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES). Trace amounts of Fe (0.012ppm) and Mn (0.017ppm) were detected in the filtrate, which revealed the stability and recyclability of the Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs. 4 Conclusions A facile and green synthesis of Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs, MnO2, and Fe3O4 using P. frutescens leaf extract is described. This environment-friendly synthetic approach is totally free of organic additives and unnecessary byproducts. The synthesized nanocomposites were used as reusable catalysts for the decolorization of rhodamine B, the reduction of 4-nitroaniline, and the sp3 C–H functionalization of 2-methylpyridines to isatins for the construction of azaarene-substituted 3-hydroxy-2-oxindole derivatives, without any significant loss of catalytic activity. These results further confirmed that the biosynthesized nanocomposites were catalytically stable and magnetically retrievable. The recovered stable nanocatalyst could be reused for further reactions. Therefore, such magnetically retrievable Fe3O4–MnO2 nanocatalysts are expected to have practical industrial applications, where recycling and reusability are essential for reducing the waste production and cost. coredata.dc:description: A novel biosynthesized nanocatalyst, iron oxide-loaded manganese dioxide nanocomposites (Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs), was fabricated with the aid of a Perilla frutescens leaf extract. The MnO2 is composed of numerous nanoflakes radiating from the center, which results to a flowerlike structure. A change in the flowerlike morphology of MnO2 in Fe3O4–MnO2 NCs was observed due to the distribution of Fe3O4 nanoparticles on the surface of MnO2. To check the catalytic performance of the synthesized NCs, they were utilized as a catalyst for the decolorization of rhodamine B (RhB), reduction of 4-nitroaniline (4-NA), and sp3 C–H functionalization of 2-methylpyridines to isatins for the synthesis of azaarene-substituted 3-hydroxy-2-oxindole derivatives. The Fe3O4-loaded MnO2 exhibited enhanced catalytic ability over MnO2. Moreover, the nanocomposites could be recovered by a magnetic separation technique and reused for five consecutive reactions without significant loss of catalytic ability.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced catalytic performance of magnetic Fe3O4–MnO2 nanocomposites for the decolorization of rhodamine B, reduction of 4-nitroaniline, and sp3 C–H functionalization of 2-methylpyridines to isatins
